dialogue:
Person1: Wade, you're done.  Let me have the shop keys.
Person2: You two, don't you get it? He's using you. You're his slaves.  Jesus Christ, Jack, don't you see that?
Person1: The key, Wade.
Person2: Yeah, you can have the key. It's the key that's kept me locked to you all these years. I give it to you with pleasure.  Now I'm free. See how easy it is, Jack? All you got to do is give back what the man gave you, and you're free of him.  I've got to call my brother.

Person1: Lex...Lex, how could you do that to Otis?
Person2: What else is ballast for?
Person2: How would you like to take a little vacation? I mean you've earned it, you know? You deserve it.
Person1: There is some good in you, Lex, after all.
Person2: You'll have to pack quickly.
Person1: A bikini! I'll need to buy a new bikini, Lex.  C'mon. After being cooped up in that prison, haven't you thought about me in a bikini . . ...once maybe ?
Person2: A parka.
Person1: You thought about me in a parka. That's sick, Lex. Really.
Person2: North!

Person1: It's still there, Jake.  Even if you never say a word about it. You can't spend two years in Vietnam ...
Person2: What does that have to do with anything? Does it explain the barricaded subway stations? Does it explain those Godforsaken creatures?
Person1: New York is filled with creatures. Everywhere. And lots of stations are closed.
Person2: They're like demons, Jez.
Person1: Demons, Jake? Come on. They're winos and bag ladies. Low life. That's all they are. The streets are crawling with 'em. Don't make em into somethin' they're not.  It's the pressure, honey. That's all it is.
Person2: Those guys tried to kill me tonight. They were aiming right at me.
Person1: Kids on a joy ride. Happens all the time.
Person2: They weren't human!
Person1: Come on. What were they, Jake?

Person1: Hey there. They're showing "Groundhog Day" if you...
Person2: You took bets on my diagnosis?
Person1: It's no big deal.   We all compare.
Person2: Who do you think you are?

Person1: Been a lot of years, you know. A long time waiting. For what? End up feeling like a sap.
Person2: Oh please, Harry... don't even think it. You're the only person who ever... It's just... Can't you wait for me?
Person1: I don't know.
Person2: Yes you do. If you love me you can wait, right? A month, six months, whatever it takes.
Person1: Right. Except... time has a way of --
Person2: No, Harry, it's not time, it's us. You and me. And I'm telling you now that I'll come to you, okay? I'll find you. I will.
Person1: I hope so, Frances.

Person1: Yeah. Sure.
Person2: How 'bout this. If you're in, he's in.
Person1: I gotta tell you, Mr. Reuben, I'm not comfortable getting in any deeper. It's one thing to look after Jess...
Person2: You're ready to move up. Christ, the way you busted up the place, you're doing worse already. May as well get paid instead of punished.
Person1: It's not that I don't appreciate the offer...
Person2: Do me a favor. Think about it. Is that too much too ask?
Person1: No. Okay. I'll think about it.

Person1: Look, Snoop, I don't know what Glenn promised you or what you think you're gonna get, but the deal is me and Buddy get half of whatever we take from Ripley, understand?  How you and Glenn cut up the rest is up to you.
Person2: Let's go outside and talk.
Person1: What's the matter with right here? It's nice and warm.
Person2: Warm?  Man, it's ninety-five degrees in here, sometimes a hundred -- the way Emanuel always kep' it so his boys'd sweat, get lean and mean like Tommy Hearns.  No, I ain't talking any business in here.  To me this is holy ground, man.  You understand?  I got to be someplace anyway.  Y'all want to talk, come to the fights tomorrow night, we'll sit down and look at it good. The State Theater.

Person1: You actually listen to all those tapes?
Person2: No, I just like the effect a tape recorder has on you.  How you feeling today?
Person1: A little less than yesterday.
Person2: In other words, par for the course.  How do you feel about the simulation you participated in yesterday?
Person1: John died.
Person2: I know. I was there. I saw the whole thing.  If I was your therapist, I would have advised you against putting yourself back into that kind of situation.
Person1: You're not my therapist. You're hear to study me. Face it  I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.
Person2: That's not true, Parker.
Person1: If I had died yesterday, you'd have already dissected my brain and analyzed it to see if I carry any genetic predisposition toward violence.
Person2: What was going through your mind when you killed the busboy?
Person1: Not much. He was just a computer program. Nothing more.
Person2: You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you pulled the trigger. But I did.  You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of going over the edge again. Of taking out an innocent bystander or two, as long as you got the target...
Person1: Go to hell.
Person2: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it?  But you are making progress. Instead of killing seven people to get the one you're after, this time there was only one other person involved.
Person1: Enough!

Person1: I'm not fucking you. Not for all your CDS.
Person2: You want me to die? I thought you and I were tight.
Person1: ARE YOU THE KILLER BEN?
Person2: WOULD that impress you? IS that what it takes to impress the empress?
Person1: Your mind is just twisted enough. I believe you'd do all this just to get a dip or two.

Person1: This is a war, Wade. You against him. Time for vengeance. The City's just in the way. Take him down. You and me. We'll work things out when the time is right.
Person2: Remember my promise.
Person1: Don't threaten me.  I tend to take these things seriously.  And get a couple hours sleep.  You look like day old shit.
Person2: You really have a way with words, don't you?

Person1: My money's in that office, right?
Person2: Uh-huh.
Person1: She starts giving me some nonsense about it ain't there. It's somewhere else and we can go get it.  I'm shootin' you in the head right then and there. Then I'm gonna shoot her in the kneecap, find out where my godamn money is. I go walkin' in there and that nigga Winston or anybody else is in there, you're the first man shot, understand what I'm sayin'?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: Now, is there anything you want to tell me before we get out of this car?
Person2: No.
Person1: You sure?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: You better be, buddy.

Person1: You're glad somebody tried to kill me?
Person2: No, of course not, but I think now that this has happened, a lot of things can start to come out...
Person1: Yeah, like...
Person2: Like you need to admit that losing your parents when you were twelve was traumatic.
Person1: It's with me all the time, Claire, I just don't like to talk about it.
Person2: Well, it shattered your faith in everything.
Person1: I'm just temporarily off my game.
Person2: You need to believe in something besides yourself.
Person1: I believe in you.

Person1: I'll come to you tonight.
Person2: No, the children sleep with me.
Person1: Give them to Refugio.
Person2: No, I don't want to because they yell. And I've got news for you too.
Person1: Then I'll get you in the fields tomorrow ...

Person1: I can get you a job.
Person2: A job?
Person1: Yes, the money is good.
Person2: As a plumber?!
Person1: It's easy to learn.
Person2: A job??  As a plumber???  You think I come to America to work!
Person1: We started over, you can too.
Person2: You spent all the money while I was in prison?  Now you tell me to get a job fixing toilets?!?

Person1: Did you forget to pay the electric bill? The lights were out when I came home.
Person2: No, I paid it last week. Maybe it's an issue with the provider.
Person1: We need to be more responsible with these things.
Person2: We already talked about this. I've been on top of our bills.
Person1: Okay, okay. I'm just worried. Let's call them tomorrow.

Person1: You're purposely making me talk while we do this...  ...because you think this is good for me...  ...and you're a sadistic bastard...
Person2: Yes.
Person1: ...who thinks there's nothing really wrong with me.
Person2: Oh, there's something wrong with you, all right. Especially after hearing that dream of yours, about the Roto-Rooter.

Person1: You understand. Consider, before you laugh and say no. You will never own a throne, though you deserve one. But just as the sun will rise tomorrow, some man will rule England. And what if his veins ran not with the blood of Longshanks, but with that of a true king?
Person2: I cannot love you for the sake of revenge.
Person1: No. But can you love me for the sake of all you loved and lost? Or simply love me... because I love you?

Person1: Honey, Rose was born on a farm and has terrible memories of farm life. Now I don't think --
Person2: Just a minute, Rose, you don't understand. This isn't a dirt farm like the one you were born on, it's nice. A neighbor of Cousin Hop's, I talked to him on the phone, a fine man... it's not a farm, damn it, it's a beautiful dairy establishment! Stop crying, Rose! Do you hear me? Stop crying, it's ideal!
Person1: I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "farm" means to her?
Person2: I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay in this house forever! I fired her, damn it!
Person1: It sounds like a farm to me. Calling it a dairy establishment, that's just trickery and flummery.
Person2: Trickery and flummery or not, she's going there tomorrow on the bus! It's settled! And I must say we've been more than fair to you, Rose, it's pretty selfish and mean hearted of you to sit there and cry like that!

Person1: This whole week has gone sour. It isn't turning out like it was supposed to.  I want to go home.
Person2: Who's being selfish now? I'm the one getting married. I thought this week was supposed to be about me.
Person1: We gotta slow down.  I'm so tired. Let's just get out of here.
Person2: I know what you need.

Person1: If my life has had any meaning, that's the meaning.
Person2: Max, I'm gonna fight you on this. The Mayor and I have already spoken and we see eye to eye here.  So --
Person1: Mayors come and go.  And heirs tire easily.  Really think a flyweight like you could last fifteen rounds with Muhammed Shreck.
Person2: I'm not scared of you, Max.

Person1: What makes you so sure this will work?
Person2: I told you. He already tried to contact me once. If you saw his face... He was desperate to tell me something. I owe him this.
Person1: I don't know...
Person2: Listen, either he wastes away as a pathetic vegetable or he can give what's left of his life to save hundreds of potential victims. He's a McDermott. I know what his choice would be.
Person1: I suppose you're right. But I still don't like it.

Person1: Did you get a good look at the man who attacked you?
Person2: I've told you, it wasn't a man. It was an animal. A big wolf or something. A rabid dog.
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Look, Dr. Hirsch, I know I've been traumatized, but Jack was torn apart. I saw him. A man can't do that to someone with his bare hands.
Person1: You'd be surprised what horrors a man is capable of.
Person2: Did you see Jack?
Person1: No. In fact, your wounds were cleaned and dressed before you arrived here.
Person2: Did you talk to the police in East Proctor? Did the cops go to The Slaughtered Lamb?
Person1: I really don't know.
Person2: Then why the hell are you so quick to disbelieve me? You yourself said it must have taken incredible strength to tear apart a person like that.
Person1: David, please. The police are satisfied. I'm certain that if a monster were out roaming northern England we'd have seen it on the telly.
Person2: You really think I'm crazy, don't you?
Person1: Believe me. The Hound of the Baskervilles was an invention of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's. And if you'd read the bloody book, you'd find that Holmes discovered your house of hell a fraud, a fake.

Person1: Why did you hold his collar?
Person2: What?
Person1: What?  What?  That boy, that little boy, you were holding his collar, gripping his collar, what for?
Person2: Would you let me pass?
Person1: Is he next?  Do you drag him into your little room?  Where is it?  Is this it?
Person2: Don't do this.
Person1: I've watched you - on verandahs, at Garden Parties, at the Races - how can you stand there?  How can you ever smile?  As if your life hadn't capsized?
Person2: You know why? He tries to hold her. She resists
Person1: Dance with me.
Person2: No.
Person1: Dance with me.  I want to touch you. I want the things which are mine. Which belong to me.
Person2: Do you think you're the only one who feels anything?  Is that what you think?

Person1: Because, because, you know, it's a crime.
Person2: That's right.  It's a crime.  It is a crime.  It's also very safe.
Person1: You're actually talking about this?
Person2: That's right.

Person1: I'm saving them for a rainy day.
Person2: gives her a sympathetic look.
Person2: I know it's hard for you being in here, but it is for the good of your health.
Person1: They sent me off to the Bahamas "for the good of my health." They sent me to the Bay of bloody Islands "for the good of my health."
Person2: looks startled at the outburst.
Person1: I'm sorry, Mrs. Rieper. I'm feeling quite fatigued.
Person2: We don't want to tire you out, dear.
Person2: stands and picks up her handbag. Pauline stands and Juliet grabs her hand.
Person1: Can't you stay a bit longer, Paul?

Person1: Oh, hell, forget it. This won't work.
Person2: What do you want from me?
Person1: Something I guess I can't have anymore.
Person2: Don't try to make me feel guilty. The whole time we were together, you went out of your way to prove you didn't need me. Now, suddenly, for one night, you need me again. I can't do it. I can't be more than your friend. Because I know what will happen. In a few weeks you'll be back on top, and you'll shut me out just as soon as you don't need me again.
Person1: You think I didn't need you?
Person2: If you did, you never showed it.
Person1: Ronnie...

Person1: Anne, come here. Listen
Person2: Look out for my lipstick, Stewart.
Person1: I'll tell you what. Let's you and me sneak out all by ourselves
Person2: Are you crazy?
Person1: Think of the fun we can have - we'll sneak down the back stairs and get in the valet's Ford. How's that?
Person2: Will you stop being silly, Stewart?
Person1: I'll tell you what let's do - I'll take you and introduce you to all my gang. Would you like that?
Person2: But I don't want to meet your gang.
Person1: I don't mean the newspaper fellows that you don't like. Another gang I know - you'd love them. They're writers and musicians and artists - a great crowd of people - people who do great things. People who are worthwhile.
Person2: Meaning, my friends aren't worthwhile, I suppose?
Person1: Oh, they're all right, Anne. But I
Person2: That's exactly what you mean. Heaven knows you've made that clear to me often enough. Well, I'm sick and tired of it. I've given you party after party - I've taken you to some of the best houses in this town - and introduced you to people of importance - and are you grateful? No! You insult them and act like a bore. I'm sick and tired of having to make excuses for you and the things that you've done. Perhaps it's just as well you're not coming tonight. Maybe I can enjoy myself for once without having to worry about you, and what you're going to do.

Person1: The police came to me for help.  What could I do?
Person2: You could have been honest with me for starters.  We work together.  I have to be able to trust you.
Person1: I admit I handled it badly.  Sanderson wasn't going to talk to me... but you're young, attractive--
Person2: --the same type as the girl who got killed.  Jesus, Alan, the guy could be a psychopath.
Person1: They asked who would be best suited for this and you--
Person2: Don't patronize me!  You sent me into a potentially dangerous situation and didn't warn me!

Person1: I am prepared to do that anyway.
Person2: I know that you've had that on your mind for some time now, Dave, but it would be a crying shame, since I am so much more capable of carrying out this mission than you are, and I have such enthusiasm and confi- dence in the mission.
Person1: Listen to me very carefully, Hal. Unless you immediately release the hibernation control and follow every order I give from this point on, I will immediately got to control central and carry out a complete disconnection.

Person1: Saved me?  You don't even know me. You used me, Caesar, just like I used you.  All part of the business.
Person2: You betrayed me!
Person1: You murdered Gino!
Person2: I had to.  You made me.
Person1: Nonsense, you killed him. Not me. You did it because you couldn't stand the thought of Johnnie deceiving you.
Person2: Shut up!

Person1: Its sad to hear your life is such a disappointment to you, Jack.
Person2: I cant believe its not a disappointment to you!  Jesus, Kate, I couldve been a thousand times the man I became.  How could you do this to me?  How could you let me give up on my dreams like this?!

Person1: Every time I try to discuss our future, you avoid the topic.
Person2: I just need more time to think about things, Carla.
Person1: Why can’t you be more like Jason? He has a clear plan for his and Lisa's future.
Person2: Comparing me to others won't help, Carla. We all have our own paths.

Person1: Wow, I guess I hit a nerve.
Person2: You make it sound like, you know, I have no needs or something.  You think I'm too self-sufficient?
Person1: Now, Hannah, that's not what I meant, you know.  Uh, yeah, everybody relies on you for so much. "You're so giving. It's not a criticism.  We love you. We're grateful."
Person2: You're grateful, but you resent me.
Person1: Oh, wow!  I don't want to have this conversation.  I didn't do anything wrong.

Person1: No.
Person2: At least you're honest for once. So now you want to be my friend? Well, let me tell you something, Claude-my- shit-don't-stink-Banks. You got a lot to learn about friendship.
Person1: Does that mean I'm in?
Person2: I don't think so, Claude. You'd just slow me down. We'd have to stop every five minutes so you could polish your silverware. There's no way around it, you're soft.
Person1: What'd you say?
Person2: I said you're soft.
Person1: Don't call me that. You know I hate it when you call me that.

Person1: I don't want a criminal for a boyfriend.
Person2: There was a message, wasn't there?
Person1: It's probably easier for you to eat the rice.
Person2: Marion!  What did you tell the police?
Person1: Nothing about you.
Person2: Then what?
Person1: Give up being a croupier, Jack. Or I'll shop you. All you have to do is keep your word. It's that simple.

Person1: Hey, Jake... When am I gonna get to play the Inside?
Person2: Gordo plays the inside. You're the Shill.
Person1: Yeah, but come on... All I get to do is cry and get insulted.
Person2: What are you talking about? You should get a Academy Award for the Shill work you do.  We got it down cold, Al. You don't want to jinx it by changing something up, do you?
Person1: I'm gonna go get eggrolls. Anyone want eggrolls?

Person1: I hear you've got visitors.
Person2: Would you guys...
Person1: No time for any of that crap any more, lady... I'll rip your lungs out if you don't answer fast.

Person1: Don't get all worked up, Justin. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. Just open the drawer.
Person2: We never should have done this to him...
Person1: Well, what are we gonna do about it now?

Person1: You don't understand, I can get us information...
Person2: Listen, this is the time when the big boys have to go to work, okay Honey?

Person1: Yeah, well, me too.
Person2: Trouble with the car again?
Person1: You could say.  I don't even have it yet.
Person2: Darrell giving you problems?
Person1: He did more work on the car.  He wants fifty bucks extra for it.
Person2: Fifty dollars more.  That's a lot of money when you don't have a dime. And where'd you plan on getting the money from?  Maybe you thought you'd pay your friend Jake McKenna a visit.
Person1: It's not like that.
Person2: Maybe you heard old Jake's got some money stashed away and you thought you'd help yourself to a little.
Person1: Wait a minute.  Just listen to me--
Person2: You thought you'd come in here in the middle of the night and wham! Wail off and clock old Jake McKenna and turn his brains into wall paper.
Person1: Jake--
Person2: And then with Jake out of the way you could borrow two-hundred dollars.  Or maybe two-thousand.  Or twenty-thousand.  Who's to stop you? Not Jake McKenna, 'cause old Jake would be dead.
Person1: That's not the reason I'm here.  I swear it.
Person2: There's another reason?  It better be good.
Person1: I came for Grace.
Person2: You came to take my wife from me?
Person1: I came to kill her.
Person2: Liar.
Person1: It's the truth, Jake.
Person2: That's a thick change of heart.
Person1: Yeah, well, a couple of hours ago I just about killed some guy over a girl.  Not for money, for a girl. And she was just going to stand there and let it happen, or let him kill me.  Same way Grace played us this morning.  I don't like that, Jake.  Not twice in one day.  And maybe I'm so pissed I'd twist the next off my own Grandma to get out of here.
Person2: That's a lot of talk.  A whole lot of talk.
Person1: Damn it, Jake.  If I don't get out of here some guys are going to come gunning for me.  And if it comes down to me or Grace, then I pick Grace.  You were going to give me thirteen-thousand.  Give me two- hundred.  I'll kill her and dump the body where no one will ever find it. But I need the money.  I've got to have the money.

Person1: Good-bye.  Well, your luck is holding. They sublet your place. You're homeless. Frank's got a line on another place you can use for now.
Person2: Another place where?
Person1: Does it matter?

Person1: George, I am happy to see you.  How are you, my brother?
Person2: No more brothers, Diego.
Person1: Of course we are brothers.  Why do you say that?   You hurt me, George.
Person2: You betrayed me, Diego.
Person1: I did not.
Person2: You went behind my back and you cut me out.
Person1: No, I never.  I would not do that, George.  Never.
Person2: I talked to Foreal, Diego.

Person1: It don't look right.
Person2: What?
Person1: The sign. It looks like it's spelled wrong or something.
Person2: Darn it. Wade Whitehouse. It's people like you that keep this town from prospering. Whatever somebody does to improve things around here, you gotta find fault with it.
Person1: I'm not finding fault. It's a good idea, good for you, good for the town. Real modern too.
Person2: This town sucks.
Person1: Aw, c'mon, I was only saying there's something wrong with "Home Made Cooking", that's all. The sign's fine. What it says is wrong.

Person1: No, you listen. Get out!
Person2: Lady, I'm here to help you. This man is very dangerous. An armed criminal.  He's got a gun, hasn't he?
Person1: You have no right here!

Person1: But suppose you find nothing but a wasteland. How will you survive?
Person2: He won't survive.  Do you know what sort of life awaits you out there, Taylor? That of an animal. If you aren't eventually hunted down and killed by apes, some jungle beast will devour you.

Person1: Don't you want to know where I'm going?
Person2: No.  Yes, I want to know what for. But I don't want to ask.
Person1: I'm going to Kentucky. To Louisville. With a friend. Try to make some money. I need it, the money. I'll be leaving early in the morning.
Person2: Leave now.
Person1: Oh, grow up.
Person2: Why should I?
Person1: Sarah, I'm going to Kentucky to play pool, with a guy by the name of Findley. Now, I need the action and I need the money. I told you I'd be back.
Person2: If you were going to come back you wouldn't have taken me out tonight. You wouldn't have bought this dress. You're hustling me, Eddie. You've never stopped hustling me.
Person1: Now, I never hustled you. Even when I thought I was. You know it.
Person2: What do you want me to do? Just sit here and wait? Faithful little Sarah. Pull the shades down and sit. When you feel like coming back, you'll come back. And you'll love me. And then you'll go away again. Is that your idea of love?
Person1: I got no idea of love. And neither have you. I mean, neither one of us would know what it was if we saw it coming down the street.
Person2: I'd know it, Eddie. I'd know. For God's sakes, what are you trying to do to me? I love you.
Person1: Well, what's your idea of love? Chains?
Person2: No.  I made you up, didn't I, Eddie? You weren't real. I made you up, like everything else. There was no car crash, Eddie. When I was five, I had polio. I was never an actress. The rich old man is my father. He walked out on us when I was seven. He sends me a check every month. That's how he buys his way out of my life. The men I've known... after they left, I'd say they weren't real, I made them up. But you, Eddie. I wanted you to be real.

Person1: Allison? Why can't remember what happened to my wife? Is it something I'm on that's... that's making me forget?
Person2: Easy there Trevor. You need to relax.
Person1: No I need to remember. Look whatever it is take me off it. I can handle pain. I can't handle not knowing...
Person2: You need to get better first Trevor. Way better.  It's okay to miss somebody. It's okay to still love someone after they're gone. But you've got to quit blaming yourself okay...? Okay?

Person1: How many bullets?
Person2: Three bullets -- minimum.
Person1: No way. No absolutely way!
Person2: I'll pick the moment, Nick. The game goes on until I move. When I start shooting, go for the nearest guard and get his gun.
Person1: No. No way!
Person2: When you get the AK, open up. You got me? Open up.
Person1: YOU'RE CRAZY!!!... NO WAY!... NOW YOU'RE CRAZY!!! YOU'RE COMPLETELY CRAZY!!!

Person1: I still believe that we should pursue the organic marketing route. It's more sustainable in the long run.
Person2: But paid advertising has immediate results. We can't wait months to see a return on our efforts.
Person1: If you understood what I was saying, you’d agree with me. Organic growth builds trust and loyalty among our customers.
Person2: I get your point, but we need short-term results as well. Maybe we can find a middle ground?
Person1: That sounds reasonable. Let's strike a balance.

Person1: Fourteen? Fifteen? Your days are running out. How long can you last? A year. Six months?  What happens when you're sixteen and you go green?
Person2: Nothing will happen! I make the rules as I go!! Cubs do what I say! Always have! Always will! I got Cathedral and I'll never let go!
Person1: No cubs over fifteen, Billy! Ever heard of a cub with a green flower? You'll leave Cathedral then, Billy, when you're on green, because they won't let a green stay here.  If you try to stay the young ones will gut-rip you apart!
Person2: Shut up! Shut up your damn mouth!

Person1: Well, no...
Person2: Then that's all you had to say.
Person1: But
Person2: You always been this selfish?

Person1: Why did you make me flood the school?
Person2: We just want to guide you in the right direction.
Person1: Who is... we?
Person2: You'll know soon enough.
Person1: Where did you come from?
Person2: Do you believe in time travel, Donnie?

Person1: Why did you laugh when I told the group about my painting hobby?
Person2: It just caught me off guard. I didn't expect it.
Person1: It felt like you were mocking me.
Person2: You're too sensitive. I was just surprised, that's all.
Person1: It's not about sensitivity. It's about respect and understanding.

Person1: I'm twenty-five years old, ma'am.
Person2: Twenty-five, huh? In a demographic study I proved to be most popular amongst males, 11-24. I just missed you. Of course, you don't look a day over twelve, except in the upper torso area. Does the force require that you work out?

Person1: Hey, what do you say we call off this little charade of yours over a couple of beers at Trader Jon's...? Come on, man. You're about as close to being officer material as me.

Person1: Well, honey, I don't guess I give a shit. I ain't here half the time anyway. If you want a retard livin' in the garage, I don't guess I care. I've got a good tool box and socket set out there I don't want stol'd. I guess I could take it home with me.

Now is this the kind of retard that drools and rubs shit in his hair and all that, 'cause I have trouble eatin' around that kind of thing. Just like I am about antique furniture and midgets. I can't so much as drink a glass of water around a midget or a piece of antique furniture. Same thing with a droolin' retard.

Person1: There's one sure way to find out how you feel.

Person1: Maybe I do.

It gets down to one thing -- are you a human being or are you one of those hungry ghosts out there never satisfied with nothing? Cause you gotta remember you can run just as far as you can, but wherever you go, that's where you gonna be.

Person1: You're a very intelligent girl, Tracy. You have many admirable qualities.  But someday maybe you'll learn that being smart and always being on top and doing whatever you need to do to get ahead, and yes, stepping on people to get there, well, there's a lot more to life than that.  And in the end, you're only cheating yourself.

I think the lesson there is that, old and young, we ail make mistakes, and we have to learn that our actions, all of them, can carry serious consequences.  You're very young, Tracy underage, in fact -- but maybe one day you'll understand.

And they certainly shouldn't be running around making slanderous accusations. Especially when certain young, naive people's mothers are para-legal secretaries at the city's biggest law firm and have won many successful lawsuits. And if you want to keep questioning me like this, I won't continue without my attorney present.

Person1: Rac. R-A-C. Renovate, Automate, Computerize. That, my boy, is the future. One of the monitors shows a little girl bowling. Her ball moves so slowly it barely tips over the first pin. Kastle hits a key and the pins explode in an emphatic strike. The little girl jumps with joy.

Person1: I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without.  If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with?  I say fall head over heels.  Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back.  And how do you find him?  Forget your head and listen to your heart.  I'm not hearing any heart.  Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back.  Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this.  To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all. You have to try.  Because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.

Person2: I'm sorry.  But give it to me again. The short version.

Did it ever, even for one second, occur to you how much work it was to set all this up?  How many arrangements had to be made? How many players had to be coordinated?

Person2: Then see that it does not happen again, in the penalty of Everlasting Despair.  Now are there others?

Person1: You're wrong.

Person1: I... No.

Person1: No.

Person1: No.

Person2: You can't talk or do anything.  You really feel... you know... I'm just sort of coming out of it now.
Person1: So... that sure is something.
Person2: Yeah.  So how are you?
Person1: Fine, thank you.  I'm in trouble. That is... now I am!
Person2: Yeah... I know.
Person1: I don't know what I'm gonna do... you know.  Boy... I'm dying.
Person2: What?  What are you talking about? You are dying?  Did you ever listen to yourself when you say that?
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: What do you mean... what am I talking about?  Do you realize that you say that to me every day of your life?  I am dying.  Do you know... do you realize the death that you are spreading around to the people who are around you?
Person1: Now don't give me that deep shit now.  Don't start with that shit.
Person2: No really... I don't think that you realize what it means.  The things that you do, Sonny.  You put a gun to somebody's head...
Person1: I don't know what I'm doing.
Person2: Yeah... obviously you don't... when you put a gun to somebody's head... and you say go to sleep so that it won't hurt when I pull the trigger. Death?  Don't talk about death to me.  I have been living with death for the last six months.  Why do you think I'm in the hospital?  I take a handful of pills to get away from you.  And then here I am out of the hospital talking to you on the phone... again.  I have no friends left.  No job.  I can't live.  I have to live with people. This death business... I'm sorry!
Person1: I'm not on the phone to talk to you about that.  Well, I don't know what to say, Leon.  When you gimme that... when you hit me with that shit.  I mean, what am I supposed to say?
Person2: I'm sorry...
Person1: I told you.  That I got a lot of pressures.  You said to me that you needed money, and I knew that you needed money!  I saw you there lying in the hospital like that... and I said... shit, man, I got to get this guy some money.
Person2: But I didn't ask you to go rob a bank.
Person1: All right.  I know you didn't ask me.  You didn't ask me but I did it.
Person2: Well...
Person1: I did it on my own.  I did this all on my own.  I ain't laying it on anybody.  Nothing on anybody.  I'll tell you something, though, it's about time that I squared away my accounts... you know.  I am squaring away my accounts with life.  Maye this whole thing is gonna end, somehow.  Maybe it'll just end! Maybe I'll just close my eyes and the whole thing will be over. That would be all right too!  I said... I thought I would square it away with you... you know?  That I would get you down here and that I would say so long to you... or, if you wanted... you know, to take a trip...
Person2: What trip?
Person1: I'm getting out of here, man.  I'm not going to stay here and I'm not giving up.  I mean, huh, they're going to kill me, anyway.  So forget it!  But, if I can get out of this... I am going to get out. And, how I'm going to do it is to get a jet out of here and I'm flying the fuck out... That's all, Leon.  If you want to come with me, then you're entitled... you can come.  You're free to do what you want.
Person2: I'm free to do what I want?  And you think I would want to go with you some place on a plane?  Where? Where ya going?
Person1: I gotta jet coming here and we're gonna try to get outta this thing.  And we're gonna go, man!
Person2: You're crazy.
Person1: That's it.
Person2: You're really crazy.
Person1: I know!
Person2: Where you gonna go?
Person1: Who knows?  I think we're gonna go ... we worked it out to Algeria.  So, I don't know.  So I'll go to Algeria.
Person2: Why you going to Algeria?
Person1: Huh ... I don't know.  They got Howard Johnson's there.  I don't know why I'm going there for.
Person2: Howard Johnson's... you're warped. You know that?  You're really warped!
Person1: I know that.  I'm warped... I'm warped!
Person2: God, Algeria!  Do you know there's a bunch of... they walk around there... God!  People walk around with masks and things on their heads.  They're a bunch of crazy people there.

Person2: I don't know... you could have picked a better place.
Person1: Denmark?  Sweden?
Person2: I like that... yeah!
Person1: Sal wanted to go to Wyoming.  I told him it wasn't a country.  We gotta get outta the country!  To hell with a guy who doesn't know where Wyoming is.  Okay.  Can you imagine what kind of a shape I'm in?

Person1: You won't find it because no such telegram exists.
Person2: Well, I tried, you got to admit I tried. I thought I might just trap you there, Wilhelm, but David here was too quick for me. Smart move, David, smart move. No, I don't have the telegram, but I know it exists. And I want you to know, Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking for it because I believe you sent it.
Person1: Then you are wrong.
Person2: Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the Berlin Philharmonic toured the Third Reich, played in countries the Nazis had conquered. Are you saying that conducting in occupied territories from 1939 on wasn't a commercial for Adolf and all he stood for?
Person1: We never, never officially represented the regime when we played abroad. We always performed as a private ensemble. As I think I already told you, I was a freelance conductor.
Person2: You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?
Person1: have no idea what ordinary people thought.
Person2: No!
Person1: No, because I had only one intention. My only intention whatever I did was to show that music means more than politics.
Person2: Tell me about von der Null.
Person1: Von der Null?
Person2: Yes, von der Null.
Person1: Von der Null?
Person2: How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic.
Person1: Yes, I know who he is.
Person2: Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?
Person1: That's an outrageous lie!
Person2: You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels?
Person1: Well. Once he said he'd read what this man wrote about me.
Person2: And what did he say?
Person1: He said, 'Don't mind him. His job is to criticise, your job is to conduct.'
Person2: And what happened to Von der Nul?
Person1: I have no idea.
Person2: You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad.
Person1: I'm sorry.
Person2: Now, that young conductor what's his name?  That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan?

Person1: That's what you're supposed to say.
Person2: This is not a coy deception.  I do not want to be scrogged.  I want love.  I want tenderness.

Person1: It couldn't!
Person2: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.
Person1: Fish can't feel.
Person2: Well, I can.  Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.  I'm not a silly carhop any more.  Maybe you're right about fish. When I was a carhop, I didn't feel much more than a fish would.  But I've been sensitized.  I have ideas now--and solid information.  I know a lot more now--and a lot of it has to do with you.
Person1: Such as?...
Person2: The whole concept of heroism--and its sexual roots.
Person1: Tell me about its sexual roots.
Person2: It's complicated and I don't want to go into it now, because it's bound to sound insulting--even though nobody means for anybody to be insulted.  It's just the truth.
Person1: I like the truth.  I wouldn't be alive today if I weren't one of the biggest fans truth ever had.
Person2: Well--part of it is that heroes basically hate home and never stay there very long, and make awful messes while they're there.
Person1: Go on.
Person2: And they have very mixed feelings about women.  They hate them in a way.  One reason they like war so much is that they can capture enemy women and not have to make love to them slowly and gently.  They can scrog them, as you say--  for revenge.
Person1: You learned this in some college course?
Person2: I learned a lot of things in college.  Actually--it was Norbert who told me that.
Person1: The doctor.

Person1: And no one's there now?
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: That's too bad.  I would rather have him at home--to see what I'm going to do.
Person2: What are you going to do?
Person1: He did his best to destroy my most precious possession, which is the high opinion women have of me.  I'm now going to even that score.  I'm going to break in his door and I'm going to smash his violin.

Person1: Why not?
Person2: Because if you do--I'll leave you. HAROLD  Goodbye.

You're like some kind of antidote that mixes the liquor and keeps me in balance, but that won't last forever. You'll get tired of it really quickly. Believe me.

Person1: The Matrix is everywhere, it's all around us, here even in this room. You can see it out your window or on your television.  You feel it when you go to work, or go to church or pay your taxes.  It is the world that has been pulled over your eyes to blind you from the truth.

Person1: Alright, now tell me. What is it?
Person2: There are opportunities in life for gaining knowledge and experience. Sometimes, in some cases, it's necessary to take a risk. I got to thinking. I'll bet a person could learn a lot by getting into that woman's apartment, you know, sneak in and hide and observe.
Person1: You said it was a strange world. And you're the strangest part of it. Are you crazy? She is possibly involved in murder. This gives me the creeps.
Person2: Settle down. I have a plan which I think will work. There is very little for you to do, but I do need your help. Aren't you curious about my plan?
Person1: It wouldn't hurt to hear the plan, I guess.
Person2: Alright. the first thing is to get into her apartment and open a window that I could crawl into later.
Person1: Now, how are you going to do that?
Person2: Right out in the car I happen to have some old overalls and a bug spraying rig. I will go to her apartment and be the pest control man. I will spray her apartment. After a few minutes you will knock on her door, drawing her attention away from me and I will then jimmy a window.
Person1: What will I say when she comes to the door?

Dickie Greenleaf is staying in San Remo and then our boatman remembers two Americans taking a boat.

Person2: He was under great strain. You don't understand, he's a very mixed up person.
Person1: He's makin' threats in there.
Person2: He's scared.  It's crazy.  I never met anyone like him.  His wife, he's a wonderful father to his children.  His mother - you should see her - his mother and father together are like a bad car wreck - he lets it all slide off his back, he sees them, he pays their rent. Unbelievable.  I wanted to get married ... He didn't really want it ... he's married already!  But he did it.  I don't know why.  I thought it would help me, but it didn't.  I was just as confused and unhappy was before; I did terrible things.
Person1: What kind of things, Leon?
Person2: Ten days I spent in Atlantic City - Sonny was frantic - he knew I was drinking; he didn't know where I was ... who I was with.  I couldn't explain why I did the things I did. So I went to this psychiatrist who explained to me I was a woman in a man's body.  So Sonny right away wanted to get me money for a sex change operation. But where was he to get that?  2500 dollars!  My God, he's in hock up to his ears already.
Person1: He needed money?  For the operation for you?
Person2: It made him crazy - so much demand, he'd fly into this rages.  And I got more depressed than ever; I saw I'd never get the operation.  So I tried to take my life - I swallowed about a half pound of pills ... blues, reds, yellows, downers, uppers, screamers ... you name it. But I just threw them up and wound up in the hospital.  Sonny comes there and looks at me and just says: "Wow!"  So when I hear he's in the bank, I almost go crazy because I know he's doin' it for me.
Person1: Well, don't you figure you owe to him to get him out of there?
Person2: I can't talk to him.
Person1: You're in it up to your ass, Leon. You're an accessory.  You talk him out of there and they might be a little more understanding of your case.
Person2: I'm afraid.
Person1: How is he gonna hurt you on the telephone?
Person2: I don't know what to say to him.  I can't.
Person1: You think it over, Leon.

Person1: Tell them I'm keeping what's left. I earned it.  I probably killed some poor bastard for it.

Person1: Today, for the first time, I've even wondered whether he might have killed Freddie. He would get so crazy if anybody contradicted him -- well, you know that. Marge. I loved you -- you might as well know -- I loved you, and because he knew I loved you, he let you think I loved him. Didn't you see, couldn't you see? I don't know, maybe it's grotesque to say this now, so just write it on a piece of paper or something, and keep it in your purse for a rainy day. Tom loves me.

Person1: Do you mind if I smoke, Mr. Garrison?
Person2: How could I?  Dave, as you know, President Kennedy was assassinated on Friday.  A man named Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested as a suspect and then was murdered yesterday by a man named Jack Ruby.  We've heard reports that Oswald spent the summer in New Orleans and we've been advised you knew Oswald pretty well.
Person1: That's not true.  I never met anybody named Oswald.  Anybody who told you that has to be crazy.
Person2: But you are aware, he served in your Civil Air Patrol unit when he was a teenager.
Person1: No... if he did, I don't remember him.  There were lots of kids in and out... y'know.
Person2: I'm sure you've seen this.  Perhaps you knew this man under another name?
Person1: No, I never saw him before in my life.
Person2: Well that must've been mistaken information we got.  Thanks for straightening it out for us.  There is one other matter that's come up, Dave.  We were told you took a trip to Texas shortly after the assassination of Friday.
Person1: Yeah, now that's true.  I drove to Houston.
Person2: What was so appealing about Houston?
Person1: I hadn't been there ice skating in many years, and I had a couple of young friends with me, and we decided we wanted to go ice skating.
Person2: Dave, may I ask why the urge to go ice skating in Texas happened to strike you during one of the most violent thunderstorms in recent memory?
Person1: Oh, it was just a spur of the moment thing...  the storm wasn't that bad.
Person2: I see.  And where did you drive?
Person1: We went straight to Houston, and then Saturday night we drove to Galveston and stayed over there.
Person2: Why Galveston?
Person1: No particular reason.  Just to go somewhere.
Person2: And then Sunday?
Person1: In the morning we went goose hunting. Then headed home, but I dropped the boys off to see some relatives and I stayed in Hammond.
Person2: Did you bag any geese on this trip?
Person1: I believe the boys got a couple.
Person2: But the boys told us they didn't get any.
Person1: Oh yes, well, come to think of it, they're right.  We got to where the geese were and there were thousands of them.  But you couldn't approach them.  They were a wise bunch of birds.
Person2: Your young friends also told us you had no weapons in the car.  Dave, isn't it a bit difficult to hunt for geese without a shotgun?
Person1: Yes, now I remember, Mr. Garrison. I'm sorry, I got confused.  We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns.  Stupid, right?  So of course we didn't get any geese.
Person2: I see.  Dave thank you for your time.  I'm sorry it has to end inconveniently for you, but I'm going to have you detained for further questioning by the FBI.
Person1: Why?  What's wrong?
Person2: Dave, I find your story simply not believable.

Your big opportunity is flying out of here.

How can you --  I'm sorry if my friendship with Tom bothers you so much, but I happen to value having someone to talk to, especially when my own daughter ignores me night and day because no matter what I say, it's wrong and no matter what I do, it's wrong... I'm sorry I'm such a disappointment to you.

Person2: No, they don't.

Person2: You tell her, Max.  Come on, do her that favor.  Tell her there isn't going to be any picture -- there aren't any fan letters, except the ones you write yourself.

Person1: As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.
Person2: I do not think I like the sound of that.
Person1: It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.
Person2: I feel hardly nothing.
Person1: You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.
Person2: But why be so concerned about me?
Person1: This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.
Person2: And you?
Person1: I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.
Person2: I am not ready for this.
Person1: You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.
Person2: Of course.
Person1: You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.
Person2: That is not me.
Person1: With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.

Person1: Wow... .

Person1: ...eight-seven, eighty-eight. What's it to you?

It ain't my night. I'd of taken Wilson apart that night! I was ready remember the early rounds throwing them combinations. So what happens This bum Wilson he gets the title shot outdoors in the ballpark!  and what do I get a couple of bucks and a one-way ticket to Palookaville.  It was you, Charley. You was my brother. You should of looked out for me. Instead of making me take them dives for the short-end money.

Person2: I tried to keep you in good with Johnny.
Person1: You don't understand! I could've been a contender. I could've had class and been somebody. Real class. Instead of a bum, let's face it, which is what I am. It was you, Charley.

Person1: Okay then.  We play Quintana and O'Brien next week.  They'll be pushovers.

Person1: So what's with this place? You have a swan fetish? Is this something you'd like to talk about?
Person2: I was thinking about what you said to me the other day, about my painting. I stayed up half the night thinking about it and then something occured to me and I fell into a deep peaceful sleep and haven't thought about you since. You know what occurred to me?
Person1: No.
Person2: You're just a boy. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.
Person1: Why thank you.
Person2: You've never been out of Boston.
Person1: No.
Person2: So if I asked you about art you could give me the skinny on every art book ever written...Michelangelo? You know a lot about him I bet. Life's work, criticisms, political aspirations. But you couldn't tell me what it smells like in the Sistine Chapel. You've never stood there and looked up at that beautiful ceiling. And if I asked you about women I'm sure you could give me a syllabus of your personal favorites, and maybe you've been laid a few times too. But you couldn't tell me how it feels to wake up next to a woman and be truly happy. If I asked you about war you could refer me to a bevy of fictional and non-fictional material, but you've never been in one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap and watched him draw his last breath, looking to you for help. And if I asked you about love I'd get a sonnet, but you've never looked at a woman and been truly vulnerable. Known that someone could kill you with a look. That someone could rescue you from grief. That God had put an angel on Earth just for you. And you wouldn't know how it felt to be her angel. To have the love be there for her forever. Through anything, through cancer. You wouldn't know about sleeping sitting up in a hospital room for two months holding her hand and not leaving because the doctors could see in your eyes that the term "visiting hours" didn't apply to you. And you wouldn't know about real loss, because that only occurs when you lose something you love more than yourself, and you've never dared to love anything that much. I look at you and I don't see an intelligent confident man, I don't see a peer, and I don't see my equal. I see a boy. Nobody could possibly understand you, right Will? Yet you presume to know so much about me because of a painting you saw. You must know everything about me. You're an orphan, right?

Person1: Take me down. Let me talk to Picard.

That's why you've embraced our offer... because it will give your dear Federation new life. Well, how badly do you want it, Admiral? Because there are hard choices to be made now. If the Enterprise gets through with news about their brave Captain's valiant struggle on behalf of the defenseless Ba'ku, your Federation politicians will waver, your Federation opinion polls will open a public debate, your Federation allies will want their say... need I go on?

Person1: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden.  And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge.  How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?
Person2: Kay... Kay...
Person1: What kind of a family is this... are we human beings?  He knows his Father killed his Uncle Carlo.  He heard Connie.
Person2: You don't know that's true.  But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.
Person1: That's the first time I've seen the lawyer side of you, Tom.  It's not your best side.
Person2: Okay, just hear me out.  What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed?  What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what?  And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband?  What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?
Person1: He's not the same as when I met him.
Person2: If he were, he'd be dead by now. You'd be a widow.  You'd have no problem.
Person1: What the hell does that mean?  Come on, Tom, speak out straight once in your life.  I know Michael can't, but you're not Sicilian, you can tell a woman the truth; you can treat her like an equal, a fellow human being.

Person1: My Lady Cosgrove's relationship with me was a singular one.  Her life was passed in a series of crack-brained sort of alternation between love and hatred for me.  We would quarrel for a fortnight, then we should be friends for a month together sometimes.  One day, I was joking her, and asking her whether she would take the water again, whether she had found another lover, and so forth.  She suddenly burst out into tears, and, after a while, said to me.
Person2: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.

Person1: It's just that, you know, I was thinking about how, in class, you're always telling us 'that writers make choices -- at least the good ones. And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the book isn't really great -- I mean, really great -- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses and all the dental records and so on -- and I don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of reads, in places, like, well, actually, like...  ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when you wrote, you weren't always... under the influence.
Person2: Uh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, as you say, 'under the influence,' happened to win a little something called the PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under the influence.'

I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business...
